author: ryanleeschneider
content:
I mentioned this in 1559-dev but whats the status of EIPs for the JSONRPC changes for tx metadata? 

> There's the suite of EIPs (3041 etc) for adding baseFee to the block RPCs, are there similar EIPs in the works for the RPC changes for transactions, for example changes to  eth_getTransactionByHash and eth_getTransactionReceipt etc for EIP-1559/2718/2930?  I see that quilt branch uses terms like gasFee, inclusionFee and accessList but it's not clear to me that besu for example is using the same JSON names for these fields.

author: ryanleeschneider
content: I'm just catching up on the ACD video from this morning, but RE: testnet fork dates.  I didn't hear this raised but at least for geth my understanding is that this will _also_ be the first release of 1.10.0 meaning lots of other potential for breakage not related to the fork itself.  Im not super excited about upgrading all our testnet infrastructure to brand new point release in such a small window, especially since we also potentially have to make other changes to our infra beyond just upgrading the nodes around supporting 2718/2930 (which is dependent on JSONRPC changes that don't have an EIP associated with yet).

author: ryanleeschneider
content: Personally I'd prefer taking things in a more staggered approach and set the fork block for one testnet, then see if that succeeds, then set the other testnet fork blocks, and then mainnet.

author: ryanleeschneider
content: My reading of https://medium.com/ethereum-cat-herders/shedding-light-on-the-ethereum-network-upgrade-process-4c6186ed442c was that the fork would only happen on ropsten to start ("Mainnet Phase / Public Testnet")

author: ryanleeschneider
content:
ok, after going through the RPC list its actually a subset of the EIP-1559 list:

```
Single transaction RPCs that need to include access list if targeting a 2930 tx:

 eth_getTransactionByBlockNumberAndIndex
 eth_getTransactionByBlockHashAndIndex
 eth_getTransactionByHash

Block RPCs which need to include access list if block contains any 2930 txs (and "full" param is true):

 eth_getBlockByHash 
 eth_getBlockByNumber

Not sure about transaction receipts:

 eth_getTransactionReceipt - ??? I don't _think_ access list needs to be included in receipt
 
No changes for 2930 to uncle RPCs since they only return the block header not tx bodies:

 eth_getUncleByBlockNumberAndIndex
 eth_getUncleByBlockHashAndIndex
 eth_getUncleByBlockNumberAndIndex
```

I'm not sure if there'd be any value in including the access list in the transaction receipt response.  I lean towards not including it but could definitely be convinced otherwise.

Going forward though, I'm concerned about the general ability for these existing RPCs to continue to evolve to include new transaction types as they are added, IMO writing the encoders and decoders for these are going to get very messy unless the transaction type field is made a first-class citizen of the JSON schema.  Many of the same arguments for adding a tx type prefix to the RLP format apply equally to partitioning the JSON schema for transactions by type somehow.

content: What about client frameworks like ethers.js, web3.js web3.py etc, will they be ready to handle 2930 txs in two weeks?  If not, will they silently drop the new fields or break?

author: gregthegreek
content: how do we update the jsonrpc spec?

author: gregthegreek
content: ive never actually written anything towards it before

author: ryanleeschneider
content: I _think_ the process is to write an EIP that proposes the spec changes, then once that's approved the spec at https://eth.wiki/json-rpc/API needs to be updated but not sure where that lives these days.

author: ryanleeschneider
content: So type is a single byte, which as far as I'm aware is a first in the JSONRPC spec, but I assume it'd be encoded as other `DATA` fields.  Or should it be a `QUANTITY`?   Basically would a legacy tx be type `"0x0"` or `"0x00"` Aside: should we move this discussion to <#779922457631916064> ?

author: ryanleeschneider
content: I actually lean towards QUANTITY since the RLP spec implies the type can at some point go above 0x7f by using the high bit to signal that the type is continued in the next byte.

author: ryanleeschneider
content: Anyways, here's my notes on what RPCs I believe need to change and the fields needed for them: https://gist.github.com/ryanschneider/723d8e2bce0829de9d6beb43639b6d3e

author: holiman
content: Yup, proto-eip is a good idea, to get everyone on the same page from the beginning, even if there's no 'formal' official spec
